Due to high transport costs she has been selling smaller quantities of her products such as peanut butter, maize, beans, okra, etc  This has reduced her working capital and her family income. She wants to use the loan to buy  larger quantities of peanuts for butter, maize, beans, etc to increase inventory and income. She believes this loan would help her save some for her children’s future. Ayeshetu is a member of the group called “Adom no nti” meaning Because of Grace. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. Ayeshetu is seated first on the left side in the photo and the others are her children.

loans.use: To buy bags of peanuts to make peanut butter, maize, beans, etc

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
Mr. Julio M. works hard at his business selling staple grains in the Israel Lewites market in the city of Managua, Nicaragua. He has spent 28 years working at this business and has successfully obtained a space where he sells his grains. He weighs the grains on his scale before handing over the product his customer had ordered.

His great efforts are due to his responsibility for caring for his young son who is of school age. He wants his son to develop intellectually, and the sale of grains is the only income he has to maintain his home.

Mr. M. has turned to CEPRODEL to request a loan in order to purchase staple grains and sell them in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

El caballero Julio M. se dedica con mucho esfuerzo al negocio de venta de granos básicos en el Mercado Israel Lewites de la ciudad de Managua. Se dedica a esta labor desde hace mas de 28 años habiendo logrado obtener un tramo propio donde vender sus granos básicos los cuales los balancea en una balanza para entregar según el pedido de sus clientes.

Sus grandes esfuerzos se deben a que tiene la responsabilidad de mantener a su pequeño hijo en edad escolar para que se desarrolle intelectualmente y la venta de granos básicos es el único ingreso que percibe para mantener su hogar.

El motivo por el cual acude a CEPRODEL es para solicitar un crédito para adquirir los granos básicos y así comercializarlos en su sector de mercado.

loans.use: Purchase staple grains

loans.name: Safura

texts.en: Safura is 35 years old and is the mother of four children. All her children are in school. She cooks rice and vegetables and sells in the local market to busy  traders.  She treks to northern Ghana to buy the rice and supplies to others in the cooking business. She also cooks some to make additional income. Due to high transport costs, Safura wants to buy more bags of rice, cartons of frozen fish and vegetables to avoid price hikes and increase inventory for a better income. She is a member of the group called Exodus. Members agree to guarantee one another for the re-payment of loans.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, frozen fish and vegetables

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora

texts.es:
The Chilito Dining Room is the name of the business to which señora Maria Auxiliadora has been dedicated for 16 years, offering all kinds of dishes for her clients.

Señora María Auxiladora is a single mother and with a son and two grandchildren that she supports because they are under age. It is necessary to emphasize that her efforts are so great that, upon doing the role of both father and mother, she has always managed to offer the children the necessary conditions so that they develop.

Nowadays the pressing need that has arisen is to obtain the money for the purchase of the commodities needed to prepare the food. For that reason she has requested of Ceprodel to obtain the necessary loan for its respective purchase.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Comedor Chilito es el nombre del negocio al que se dedica la señora Maria Auxiliadora desde hace 16 años ofreciendo todo tipo de platillos para sus clientes.

La señora María Auxiladora es madre soltera y con un hijo y dos nietos que mantener por ser menores de edad. Es necesario destacar que sus esfuerzos son tan grandes que al hacer el papel de padre y madre siempre ha logrado brindarles las condiciones necesarias para que ellos se desarrollen.

Hoy en día la necesidad que atraviesa es que le urge obtener el dinero para la compra de su materia prima para preparar los alimentos. Por este motivo acude a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito necesario para su respectiva compra.

loans.use: To buy the materials needed to make the foods that she sells in her restaurant.

loans.name: Shallotte

texts.en: Shallotte is married with one child. She used to sell only soft drinks and rice in large quantities in the neighborhood but now she has added to her  “breakfast joint” where she prepares breakfast for workers who are not able to prepare meals before going to work.  She wants to use the loan to buy more products to expand her operation. Her dream now is to turn her current place of operation into a snack bar and she has started saving towards that dream. Shallotte believes this loan will help her increase her savings to make her dream come true in the near future. She is a member of the group called El Shaddai. Members agree to guarantee for one another in the re-payment of loans.

loans.use: To buy crates of soft drinks, eggs, bread, bags of rice, etc

loans.name: Ines Veronica

texts.es:
Señora Ines M. is a native of the city of Managua. She sells food in the outskirts of the Israel Lewites market. Her location doesn't offer good conditions since she sells in the open air and needs to improve her place of business.

She is the mother of three school-aged children, and she needs to take care of them and provide them with everything necessary for their development. Today she has turned to Ceprodel to request a credit, with which she will be able to purchase supplies to make her food and to continue her business of selling food.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Ines M. es originaria de la ciudad de Managua Nicaragua y se dedica al negocio de venta de comida en las afueras del Mercado Israel Lewites. Su ubicación no presta las condiciones necesarias debido a que ella vente a la intemperie requiriendo mejorar su localidad.

Es madre de tres hijos en edades escolares con la obligación de mantenerlos y brindarles todas las condiciones necesarias para su desarrollo. Hoy en dia ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito con el cual lograr comprar su materia prima para elaborar los alimentos y continuar en su negocio de venta de comida en su localidad.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to make her food.

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua is a widow with four children. Her husband died some years back and therefore could not afford to send all of her children to school. Happily, with the loan from Sinapi, she was able to send her youngest child  to school. She was also able to start cooking rice with vegetables for school children and for people in the community. She has also enrolled her other children in a program to learn the hair dressing trade. Akusua wants to use the loan to expand her operations, increase income and add a grocery store to her business. She is a member of the group called “Nokwaredee” meaning Truthfulness. Members agree to guarantee one another for loan re-payment.

loans.use: To purchase bags of rice and vegetables

loans.name: Neydi

texts.es:
In the city of Managua, in the market of Israel Lewites, Mrs. Neydi Sanchez makes a living in her business selling fruits and vegetables.

She started her business 8 years ago by selling few products. Today, thanks to her efforts and the support provided by Ceprodel, she has increased her inventory and is able to offer greater quantities of fruits and vegetables to her clientèle.

The need which she is currently undergoing is the urgency to get funds for the purchase of products. This is why she is coming to Ceprodel to obtain the credit and in this way forge ahead with her family.

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


En la ciudad de Managua, en el Mercado Israel Lewites la señora Neydi Sanchez se dedica a su negocio de venta de frutas y verduras las cuales las comercializa en su tramo en dicho mercado.

Su negocio lo inició desde hace 8 años vendiendo pocos productos y hoy en día gracias al aporte brindado por Ceprodel ha incrementado su inventario ofreciendo mayores cantidades de frutas y verduras para sus clientes.

La necesidad que hoy en día ella atraviesa es la urgencia de adquirir el recurso económico para la compra de sus productos. Por esto es que ella acude a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito y de esta manera salir adelante junto con su familia.

loans.use: Compra de las frutas y verduras / Buying fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Agripina

texts.es:
Señora Agripina E. does agricultural work in her community of Somotillo in the city of Chinandega. Her multiple efforts have allowed her to support her home, which is composed of three small, school-aged children who she loves so much.

Right now she needs to acquire the economic resources to purchase animals to raise so she can sell their milk to her customers. For this reason, she is turning to Ceprodel. She is very confident that the credit will be offered to her and will benefit her a lot.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Agripina E. se dedica al negocio agropecuario en su comunidad de Somotillo en la ciudad de Chinandega. Sus múltiples esfuerzos han permitido que ella pueda llevar el sustento a su casa de habitación compuesta por sus tres pequeños hijos en edades escolares a los que ama tanto.

La necesidad que hoy en día atraviesa es que necesita adquirir el recurso económico para la compra de animales para la crianza por lo que al criarlo les extrae la leche la cual es comercializada a sus clientes. Por este motivo acude a Ceprodel muy confiada de que su crédito será otorgado y le será de mucho beneficio.

loans.use: Purchase of cows

loans.name: Clemente

texts.es:
Clemente is a very hard-working person who does agricultural work in Somotillo in the city of Chinandega. The cirumstances he has gone through since several years ago have made him work very hard to put bread on the table every day in his humble home. Committed to his family to improve their quality of life and due to the fact that their community is very remote, he doesn't have electricity, and he has requested the implementation of a solar panel to obtain it.

For this reason, he has come to Ceprodel to obtain a credit to pay for the solar panel. In this way, he can continue working and provide better conditions for his beloved family.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

El caballero Clemente es una persona muy trabajadora que se dedica al negocio agropecuario en el municipio de Somotillo en la ciudad de Chinandega. Las circunstancias por las cuales ha atravesado desde hace varios años han hecho que se esfuerce mas para llevar el pan de cada día a su humilde hogar. Comprometido con su familia por mejorar las condiciones de vida y debido a que en su comunidad por estar muy alejada no se cuenta con energía eléctrica, ha solicitado la implementación de un panel solar para obtener energía eléctrica.

Por esta razón acude a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito para el pago del panel solar para que de esta manera pueda continuar en su trabajo y con mejores condiciones de vida para su amada familia.

loans.use: Purchase of a solar panel for his home

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce A. is a thirty five year old divorced mother of three children that are currently in school. She owns and operates a beauty saloon in her neighborhood. Joyce is a very skillful and a talented hair dresser. She does all kinds of hair style like plaiting, perming and fixing of weave-ons etc. She believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, therefore she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weave-ons, pomade, shampoo, activators etc. to avoid shortage and poor service. She is a member of the community group called Mercy Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and utilize peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of hair products like weave-ons, pomade, shampoo, activators etc.

loans.name: Edith

texts.es:
Edith A. sells various products in her humble grocery store, which she has improved by obtaining larger quantities of products to offer. It is located in Somotillo de Chinandega.

With much effort, she sells her products with the purpose of getting ahead and offering the possibility of an education to her young son. For this reason, she has come to Ceprodel today to obtain a credit to get ahead, and in this way improve the quality of life for herself and her son, who she loves so much.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Edith A. se dedica a la venta de productos varios en su municipio de Somotillo de Chinandega atendiendo su humilde pulpería el cual a través de los años la ha venido mejorando hasta obtener mayores cantidades de productos para ofrecerlos.

Muy esforzadamente vende sus productos con el propósito de salir adelante y brindarle a su pequeño hijo las posibilidades para sus estudios. Por este motivo es que ella acude hoy en día a Ceprodel para obtener un crédito con el cual salir adelante y de esta manera mejorar las condiciones de vida de ella y su pequeño al que tanto ama.

loans.use: To purchase products for her grocery store

loans.name: Jorge Antonio

texts.es:
In the municipality of Somotillo of the city of Chinandega señor Jorge Rye C. is dedicated to the production of dairy cattle and the production of basic grains and oils. With a lot of effort and sacrifice he carries out this work every day for the purpose of improving the conditions of his family, bringing the daily bread to his table and, at the same time, saving for the improvement of his dwelling, which needs a lot of help because it is in bad state which little by little he has come to improve.

His family admires him for the fact that his multiple efforts have permitted him to bring food to his home and that in addition he has managed to keep his children in school. The need that this gentleman faces is that he needs to invest in his business through the purchase of cows for its development. By this he hopes that Ceprodel will offer him the loan to do well along with his family.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

En el municipio de Somotillo de la ciudad de Chinandega el señor Jorge C. C. se dedica a la producción de ganado lechero y la producción de granos básicos y de oleaginosas. Labor la cual con mucho esfuerzo y sacrificio la realiza todos los días con el propósito de mejorar las condiciones de su familia llevando el pan diario a su mesa y a la vez ahorrando para el mejoramiento de su vivienda el cual necesita de mucha ayuda por estar en mal estado el cual poco a poco la ha venido mejorando.

Su familia lo admira por el hecho de que sus múltiples esfuerzos han permitido que lleve el alimento a su casa de habitación y que además logre mantener a sus hijos en el colegio. La necesidad que atraviesa este caballero es que necesita invertir en su negocio por medio de la compra de vacas para su desarrollo. Por esto espera que Ceprodel le otorgue el crédito para salir adelante junto con su familia.

loans.use: To buy dairy cows to further develop his business.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama K. is forty five years old. She is a widow and the mother of two children. Through hard work, Ama has supported one of her children to finish senior high school and the other is currently in school. She is a food vendor and sells kenkey as well as maize. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and taken with hot pepper and fried fish. She has many customers since many Ghanaian enjoy kenkey as breakfast, lunch and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to  increase her income to support her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called Mercy Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and utilize peer pressure to repay the loan

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: José Porfirio

texts.es:
Señor José Porfirio, who lives in the municipality of Somotillo, is dedicated to the cattle business which he attends very diligently in his community. From very early in the morning he tends to the animals and he returns in the afternoons, having been exposed to the sun and exhausted from all this, in order to bring food to his table for his spouse and beloved children.

Ceprodel has been a great support for this gentleman because it has offered him loans that he has used for the purchase of the cows for his development. Today he once more looks for support for the purpose of buying cattle to market in his sector.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor José Porfirio se dedica en el municipio de Somotillo al negocio de Ganado el cual atiende muy esforzadamente en su comunidad. Desde muy temprano por la mañana traslada a los animales y vuelve por las tardes habiéndose expuesto al sol y al cansancio todo esto con el fin de llevar a su mesa el alimento para su cónyuge y amados hijos.

Ceprodel ha sido un gran apoyo para este caballero porque le ha brindado créditos que él mismo los ha utilizado para la compra de las vacas para su desarrollo. Hoy en día una vez mas busca el apoyo con el propósito de comprar el ganado para así comercializarlo en su sector.

loans.use: To buy cattle to raise and sell.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa A. is a fifty year old woman. She is a widow and the mother of two children. Her husband died twenty years ago and, since that time, she has been the sole bread winner of the family. Through hard work, Theresa has supported one of her children to complete senior high school but her youngest child is currently in school. She is a food vendor who sells kenkey in her neighborhood. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish. She has many customers since many Ghanaian enjoy kenkey as breakfast, lunch and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to increase her income to support her first child to enter university. She belongs to a community group called “Nyame Asem” (God’s word). In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and utilizes peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.es:
Señora Magdalena is a humble elderly lady that has been dedicated all her life to the farm business; cultivating basic grains and raising cattle in the municipality of Somotillo of the city of Somotillo. The problems that she faces in her community is that, by being in a very distant rural sector, she can not count on electric power and for this reason she has requested the installation of a solar panel for illumination and to do the tasks of the home.

She has requested of Ceprodel to obtain the loan for the payment of the solar panel. Nowadays she waits for her loan to be approved so that she may obtain the electric power that will provide of a lot of benefit. For a long time she has utilized candles for lighting and with the solar panel she will have the use of two lamps and a small television set. With this loan she will benefit and improve the conditions of her home.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Magdalena es una humilde anciana que se ha dedicado toda la vida al negocio agropecuario cultivando granos básicos y criando Ganado en el municipio de Somotillo de la ciudad de Somotillo. La problemática que atraviesa en su comunidad es que por ser un sector rural muy alejado, no se cuenta con energía eléctrica y por esto es que ha solicitado la implementación de un panel solar para iluminarse y hacer los quehaceres del hogar.

Ha acudido a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito para el pago del panel solar. Hoy en día espera que su crédito sea aprobado para así obtener la energía eléctrica que le servirá de mucho beneficio por lo que para alumbrarse por mucho tiempo ha utilizado candiles y con el panel solar tendrá acceso a dos lámparas y un pequeño televisor. Con este crédito se beneficia y mejora las condiciones de su hogar.

loans.use: To pay for a solar panel

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rafael Antonio

texts.es:
Señor Rafael Antonio is dedicated to the business of selling basic grains which he markets in the municipality of Somotillo for the purpose of improving the conditions of his humble home which he has the duty of maintaining.

He is a father of two children who he must maintain and offer the necessary conditions for their development. The problem that he faces nowadays is that, because he does not possess the economic resources, he has sought support from CEPRODEL for a loan for the purchase of the basic grains which will permit him to market them in his sector in the municipality of Somotillo of the city of Chinandega of the beautiful country of Nicaragua.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Rafael Antonio se dedica al negocio de venta de granos básicos los cuales los comercializa en el municipio de Somotillo con el propósito de mejorar las condiciones de su humilde hogar de habitación el cual tiene el deber de mantener.

Es padre de dos hijos los cuales debe de mantener y brindarle las condiciones necesarias para su desarrollo. El problema que hoy en día atraviesa es que al no poseer el recurso económico, ha buscado apoyo en CEPRODEL para ser beneficiado con el crédito que le permita la compra de estos granos básicos para comercializarlos en su sector en el municipio de Somotillo de la ciudad de Chinandega del bello país de Nicaragua.

loans.use: To buy grains for sale in the market.

loans.name: Rosina

texts.en: Rosina A. is a forty eight year divorced mother of five children who are currently in school. She is a trader and sells gari, yam, groundnuts and maize in her neighborhood. Gari is produced from milled cassava, dried and fried and it is one the local foods that is enjoyed by many Ghanaian with cooked beans and palm oil. Rosina uses part of her business profits to finance her children’s education. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of gari, tubers of yam, beans, groundnut and maize to increase her stock of goods for sale and she hopes to increase her income to pay her children’s school fees. Her greatest dream is to see all her children graduate from high school and university and that is her motivation to work. She is a member of the trust group called “Nyame Asem” (God’s work). In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and utilizes peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bags of gari, tubers of yam, beans, groundnut and maize.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah A. is sixty four years old. She is married with four children who are currently in school. Hannah is very hard working and dedicated to every piece of her business. She sells kenkey, oil and also supplies plantain suckers to farmers in her local community for planting. She sells multiple commodities to enable her earn a good income to support her children’s education. Her husband is a pensioneer. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of maize, gallons of palm oil and plantain suckers to increase her stock of goods for sale. She hopes to increase her income to pay for her children’s school fees and other educational needs. Her dream is to see all her children graduate from high school and university which motivates her to work hard. She is a member of the trust group named Daniel Nyame (God of Daniel). In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans and utilize peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize, gallons of palm oil and plantain suckers.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret K. is forty years old. She is married with five children. She is a serious minded and resourceful business woman who works hard to support her husband to provide for her family. She owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, and skimmed powdered milk.

Through this business, Margaret has supported three children to finish senior high school. She deems this loan a great opportunity that she can use to expand her business. She wants to use the loan to increase her stock of goods available for sale. She would buy more bags of rice and sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, and boxes of body and hair creams.

She belongs to the community group called Timothy Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To increase her stock of goods available for sale.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys A. is thirty five years old. She is married and given birth to a single child. Gladys is a local manufacturer of palm oil. Palm oil is produced from palm nuts. The palm nut is taken through various processes to squeeze the oil out. This is a lot of drudgery using manual means. Her operation is on a limited scale due to the lack of adequate capital to buy machine for the processing. 

She wants to take advantage of the loan to buy more raw material (palm nuts) and processing equipment to increase her efficiency and produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help her to make bigger income to finance her child’s education. She belongs to the community group called Daniel “Nyame” (God of Daniel) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more raw material (palm nuts) and processing equipment.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice D. is forty one years old. She is married with four children who are currently school. She is a food vendor and sells banku. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and taken with hot pepper plus fried fish or soup. She does her banku in a unique way. She packages it and sells to her customers at their door step. This strategy has really worked for her because she has lots of regular and new customers daily. 

She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood to further her production. She hopes to raise good income to support her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called “Sore hyiren” (Arise and shine) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and peer pressure to repay the loan. Beatrice is the photograph wearing top white blouse, together with her assistance.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica B. is forty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to five children. She is a petty trader who sells tomatoes, palm oil, yams, plantain, vegetables, beans, and maize from a table in the local market. She sells multiple commodities with the hope that when the sale of one goes down the others will sell to give her good profit. She is however convinced that her business can grow better with increased capital and therefore wants the loan to buy more tubers of yams, baskets of tomatoes and onions, bags of maize and beans. Iincreasing her stock will provide a bigger income to finance her children’s education. Currently, three of them have completed senior high school.

She belongs to the community group called Timothy Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan.

loans.use: To buy more tubers of yams, baskets of tomatoes and onions, and bags of maize and beans.

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara S. is twenty-nine years old. She is married with four children ,who are all currently in school. She works very hard, driven by a passion to provide brighter future opportunities to her children. At the moment, two of her kids are in junior high school and the other two are in primary school.

Sara is a petty trader who sells yams. She buys her yams from a town called Techiman, which is 134 km from her, and then sells them to her customers at a profit. She wants to use the loan to buy more tubers of yam that she will keep to sell in bits. This will help her avoid price hikes caused by the current food crisis in the country.

She belongs to the community group called Timothy Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more tubers of yam to keep and sell in bits.

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en:
Akosua B. is forty-two year old business woman. She is married with eight children. She is very industrious woman and her biggest wish is to provide quality education for her children in order to give them better life opportunities.

Akosua is a food vendor and sells ice kenkey. Ice kenkey is a mashed kenkey with milk and sugar, refrigerated, and then taken with bread or meat pie. Operating for the past seven years, she has supported two of her children to complete senior high school. The rest are currently in school. She wants to use the loan to add other food products to her inventory, like eggs and groundnut. This will allow her to raise more income to support the children’s education, which is her life's dream.

She belongs to the community group called Timothy Trust Group. Members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan.

loans.use: To expand her inventory with new food products, like eggs and groundnuts.

loans.name: Herty

texts.en:
Herty A. is twenty six year old business woman. She is married and ha given birth to three children. She sells porridge and groundnuts at her neighborhood. Porridge is one of the local foods enjoyed popularly as breakfast. It is prepared from milled maize or millet grains, boiled, and then taken with sugar, milk and bread. With a large customer base, she wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, millet, sugar, and milk in order to increase production. She hopes to raise enough income to support her younger brother in school.

She is a member of group called Sore hyiren (Arise and shine) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials, like bags of maize, millet, sugar, and milk.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience Q. is thirty eight years old. She is a wife and the mother of three children who are all currently in school. Through this business, Patience has supported one of her children to finish senior high school.

She is a food vendor and sells kenkey and maize. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked, and then taken with hot pepper and fried fish. She has many customers because many Ghanaians enjoy kenkey as breakfast, lunch, and supper. She wants to use this loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood. She hopes to raise her income to support her children’s education.

She belongs to the community group called Holy Trinity Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials, like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables, and firewood.

loans.name: Fahim

texts.en: Fahim lives in district 10 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has a retail shop and he has been involved in this business for more than 5 years. He took his first loan to support his business to this point. Now he wants to take his second loan to complete his inventory to become strong in his business. He is happy with this loan process that helps poor people in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To complete his inventory

loans.name: Wahid Allah

texts.en: Wahid Allah lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is educated and married with one son. He was out of Afghanistan for about 5 years and when he returned one year ago he opened a mobile phones sells shop. His business is going very well and he needs money to enlarge his shop and complete his stock to make a better income for his family.

loans.use: To enlarge his shop and complete his stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To start a small business selling used clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To start selling costume jewelry in her community.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase raw materials to keep producing pasties and arepas.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a wide range of goods to restock a small grocery store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of clothing and housewares for a small business.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina is married with four children. Her previous loan from Sinapi has helped her support one of her children to enter university and the others are currently in school. She has also registered with the government’s health insurance for free medical care.

Faustina sells rice, tilapia, eggplants, washing powder, dread, and other items to meet her loyal clients’ tastes and preferences. She wants to use the loan to buy more products to increase inventory and income. Her greatest challenge is to rent or buy her own store as she currently sells on a table in front of a friend’s house and any time it rains, business comes to a halt. She believes this loan would help her increase savings to get a store. 

Faustina is a member of the group called “Nyame ye Odo” meaning God is Love. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Lace cloth is very adorable and it is used to beautify homes as curtains, tablecloths, and decorations. This has created high demand for lace in Ghana. Mary, a married woman with two children, has made hawking of lace an enjoyable business and wants to increase her inventory. She believes this loan would help her to save. She would use her savings to register to join the national health insurance scheme to enjoy free medical care and also to support her husband to pay their children’s education.

Mary is a member of the group called Gift. Members agree together to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bales of lace cloth.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 47 year old mother with two children. She is also taking care of a sister’s child. Selling frozen foods and grocery products has been her business for ten years. Initially, she sold only frozen foods, like fish, beef, chicken, and mutton, but has now added eggs, eggplants, tinned tomatoes, and charcoal to increase her income. Florence wants to use the loan to buy more cartons of frozen foods and a deep freezer to enable her to stock more frozen foods.

She is a member of the group called “Nyame ne ye Hwefo” meaning God is our Caretaker. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of frozen foods and a deep freezer.

loans.name: Zinabu

texts.en:
Zinabu is married with six children. She prepares and sells “waakye” (cooked rice with beans and eating with vegetable sauce). She also buys brown rice, unpolished rice, peanuts, millet, beans, and maize and sell in bulk to other traders who are not able to travel to the northern Ghana where such produce are common. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of cereals and legumes to reduce frequent travels and also to avoid price hikes.

Zinabu is a member of the group called “Yehowa ne ye Hwefo” meaning God is our Caretaker. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cereals and legumes to sell.

loans.name: Millicent's Group

texts.en:
Agyenkwa Group is a group of eleven women whose name means savior. For some time now they have traded in various items, ranging from tubers and cereals to legumes and vegetables to used clothing. All these women have children; the leader has eight. She prepares and sells fufu (pounded cassava eating with soup) rice balls, banku (milled and boiled maize), and other food items.

They are hard working but due to large family sizes they spend their working capital supporting their children. They endure economic hardship and therefore came together to form the group. Members want to use the loan to buy produce and cloths to increase their income so that they can better support their families. They co-guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more fresh tubers of yams, cassava, rice, used clothing, vegetables, and other items for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a widow with five children. She lost her husband some few years back and this has increased her responsibility as a widowed mother. She started trading in fresh yams, rice onions, salt, and other food products to generate some income to take care of her children. She wants to use the loan to buy fresh yams, onions, salt, and other items for resale to both increase her inventory and income and avoid future price hikes.

Mary is a member of the group called Queens. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan. Mary’s photo was taken during a group meeting.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice, fresh tubers of yam, onions, and bags of salt.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married with six children, all of whom are currently in school. There is a big market in Ghana for selling grocery products, such as vegetable oils, margarine, washing powder, peanut butter, assorted biscuits, candies, and toiletries. And Rose has been delighted to sell groceries for four years now.

With her previous loan, Rose was able to open a store on her own and no longer needs to sell in the hot sun. She wants to use this loan to buy more products to both increase her inventory and to avoid future price hikes. She is a member of the group called Friends. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell in her store.

loans.name: Sy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sy K. earns approximately $3.33 per day growing crops behind her house. Her husband, Mr. Tit Savuth, is a bricklayer who earns approximately $6.66 per day. Together, they have one young child, who is not yet old enough to attend school.

They request a loan for $800 to buy a motorcycle to transport Mrs. Sy K.'s vegetables to the market and to reduce the expenses associated with Mr. Tit’s commute to work. The loan will allow them to increase their family’s net income and thereby improve their quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to transport her vegetables to the market and to reduce the expenses associated with her husband’s commute to work

loans.name: Leap

texts.en:
Mrs. Leap S. is a 41-year-old married mother. She lives with her husband and children in Khla Khmom Village, Siem Reap Province. One of her children is married, another works in the Siem Reap Province, and the other four attend school.

Mrs. S. earns approximately $5 per day selling groceries from her house and her husband, Mr. Thong, earns approximately the same amount building wood and bamboo beds to sell. She requests a loan of $1,200 in order to buy a gas-powered electricity generator for use for her family and home business. The loan will allow her to work outside of daylight hours and therefore increase her income.

loans.use: In order to buy a gas-powered electricity generator to use for her family and home business

loans.name: Sophorn

texts.en: Mrs. Sophorn K. lives in Kchas village in Kampong Speu province. She is a farmer and a widow. She has four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in school. Mrs. Sophorn K.’s business now has a small problem because she has doesn’t have enough draft animals to plow her rice field. Therefore, she is asking for a loan to buy another cow to be used as a draft animal. Mrs. Sophorn K. is shown in the photo with her son.

loans.use: To buy one cow to be a draft animal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of raw materials to produce pasties and candies.

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Mr. Leng S. is a subsistence farmer in Snam Pok village in Kampong Speu province. He is also a construction worker. He does not have enough plow equipment and needs some draft animals. Thus, he is applying for a loan in order to buy two cows to plow his rice field. His wife, Mrs. Kheng Rin, is also a farmer. Mr. Leng S. is 33 and is the father of six children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while four others are attending school. The youngest one is too young to work or enroll in school. His wife is also pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To buy two cows to plow the rice field

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in used clothing to sell in her community.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in shoes and slippers for a small business.

loans.name: Sokneng

texts.en: Mrs. Sokneng S. is a farmer in Snam Pok village in Kampong Speu province. Her husband, Mr. Thy Not, is also a farmer. Mrs. Sokneng S. wants to start a pig-selling business. She is asking for a loan to buy a motorbike to transport the pigs that she will sell door-to-door as well as pigs to sell. Mrs. Sokneng S. has four children, one of whom is attending school while the remaining three are at home because they are young. Her husband is also pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike in order to sell pigs door-to-door

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of clothing to resell in her community.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Mr. Vann L. is a villager in Trapaing Skun village in Kampong Speu province. He and his wife are subsistence farmers. Mr. Vann L. is also a palm juice collector. He and his wife have five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while two others are enrolled in state school. The youngest one is too young to work or study. In order to improve his living conditions, Mr. Vann L. would like to start a grocery business. Thus, he is asking for a loan to buy grocery products to start his new business. His wife is also shown in the photo.

loans.use: To buy grocery products to start a new business

loans.name: Ret

texts.en: Mrs. Ret S. lives in Trapaing Skun village in Kampong Speu province. She is a garment worker. Her husband, Mr. Mean Mi, is a construction worker. Mrs. Ret S. is 22 and recently married. She wants to start a cow breeding business to improve her standard of living. She is asking for a loan to buy a cow for this purpose. Her husband is also shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a cow in order to start a cow breeding business

payments.comment: Mrs. Ret Say has paid off her loan 10 months in advance! AMK and Kiva would like to thank you for lending to her and we hope you lend again soon! We\'ll do a journal on her very soon!

loans.name: Chamreun

texts.en: Mrs. Chamreun T. is a villager in Trapaing Skun village in Kampong Speu province. She is currently has a plantation which she cultivates twice a year. Mrs. Chamreun T.’s living conditions are poor; therefore, she wants to start a grocery store. She is asking for a loan to buy grocery products in order to start a new business. Her husband, Mr. Nget Sem, is a subsistence farmer. Mrs. Chamreun T. has three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other one is working as a construction worker. Her husband is also pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To buy grocery products in order to start her new business

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov B. and her husband, Mr. Sum Sor, are subsistence farmers in Trapaing Skun village in Kampong Speu province. She is asking for a loan to buy one more cow to be draft animal to plow on her rice field. She has eight children, two of whom are working in a garment factory while another is a construction worker. Four others are attending a local school and one is very young so they stay at home. Previously, Mrs. Pov B. obtained a loan to buy a cow for breeding. Her husband is also pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To buy one more cow to be a draft animal

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Mrs. Sokha N., who is 28 years old, lives in Yuos Chour village in Kampong Speu province. She is a farmer and a cake seller. Her husband, Mr. Kean Sambath, is a subsistence farmer. They have two children, both of whom are too young to work or attend school. Mrs. Sokha N. would like to start another cow breeding business. She has obtained  loans in the past to buy a cow and to start cake selling business. Last year, Mrs. Sokha N.’s youngest child developed cardiac hypertrophy so she had many unforeseen expenses. Mrs. Sokha N. is not in the picture but her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. Sok M. is a villager in Wat Kdey village in Kampong Speu province. She is currently in the plantation business. She is requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding in order to improve her family’s living conditions. Her husband, Mr. Phi Chon, is a subsistence farmer. Mrs. Sok M. is 36 and is the mother of three children. One of her children is employed in a garment factory and the other two are enrolled in a local school. Her husband is also pictured in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Sokong

texts.en: Mrs. Sokong S. is 22 years old. She lives in Wat Kdey Village in Kampong Speu Province. She and her husband, Mr. Saody Keo, are currently subsistence farmers. They have one child who is too young to work or enroll in school. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sokong S. would like to start a grocery business. Thus, she is asking for a loan to purchase grocery goods to sell in the local market. Her husband and her child are also shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery goods to sell in the local market.

loans.name: Saomphos

texts.en: Mrs. Saomphos P. is a villager in Kralanh Village in Kampong Speu Province. She is currently in the grocery business. Mrs. Saomphos P. would like to expand her business and increase her business activity. Therefore, she is asking for a loan to buy more grocery goods to sell to customers. She obtained a loan previously from AMK to start her business. Mrs. Saomphos P. is married. Her husband, Mr. Vutha Hang, is a motorbike-taxi driver in the local village. He is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Deam

texts.en: Deam Y., 46, grows crops and makes thatched roofing out of palm leaves. Through the sale of her goods, she earns approximately $1.67 per day. Her husband, Mr. Pong Chin, is a motorcycle-taxi driver, earning around $3.33 per day. They have three children, two of whom are married. The family lives in Momeanh Village, Siem Reap Province. Mrs. Y. seeks a loan of $100 to purchase a new motorcycle to replace the old one that her husband currently uses. The loan will allow her husband to improve his motorcycle-taxi business, and thereby increase the family income. (The photo is Y.’s husband)

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle to replace the old one that her husband currently uses

loans.name: Madawa P.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 37 year-old Madawa P. S.. She is married and has two children, aged 13 and 8. She has four dependents, who live with her because they are orphans and relatives. In 2005, Madawa established her hair salon. Madawa has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy hair dryer and also some cosmetics in bulk. In the future, Madawa plans to be a popular hair designer. She thanks you for your support.

Hair, hair and more hair! This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or plaited, and made to look like your own.

loans.use: To buy a hair dryer and some cosmetics in bulk.

loans.name: Rhoda I.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 45 year-old Rhoda I. K.. She is married and has six children, aged between 25 and 15. She has one dependent, who lives with her because she is orphan. In 1995, Rhoda established her business selling cloth. She opens her business six days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day. Rhoda requires a loan in order to buy more cloth in bulk. In the future, Rhoda plans to invest in different place in Tanzania. She thanks you for your support.

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because they are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything western or modern. Many people argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress, however the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To buy more cloth in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Itika J.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Itika J. M.. She is married and has four children between 9 and 18 years old. In 2006, Itika established her batik business. Itika has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA and now requires a new loan in order to expand her range of clothes, shoes, and handbags. In the future, Itika plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To expand her range of clothes, shoes, and handbags.

loans.name: Rose M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 45 year-old Rose M.. She is married and has four children, aged between 22 and 5. In 2007, Rose established her poultry farming business. Rose requires a loan in order to buy food and drugs for poultry farming. She thanks you for your support.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. In fact, if you are a regular lender on kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku. Who or what are ‘kuku’, you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons.

Firstly, they require little start-up capital, you can start with one or two and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiple naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular (maybe they are friendlier than other animals? Prettier?), but this is all time and space will allow.

loans.use: To buy food and drugs for poultry farming.

loans.name: Cornelia M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 28 year-old Cornelia M.. She is married and has two children, aged 6 and 4. In 2004, Cornelia established her crops business. Cornelia has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy additional stock of maize. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy additional stock of maize.

loans.use: To buy more material for cloth-making.

loans.name: Eva H.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 50 year-old Eva H. M.. She is widow with five children, aged between 30 and 17. She has three dependents, who live with her because they are orphans. In 1992, Eva established her crops business. She has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy additional stock of crops. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

loans.name: Augusta G.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 42 year-old Augusta M.. She is married and has three children, aged 21, 19, and 15. She has one dependent, who lives with her because she is orphan. In 2002, Augusta established her poultry farming business. Working six days a week, and five to eight hours a day, she earns about $40.00 every month from this business. Augusta has already received and successfully repaid four loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy chicken, drugs, and food. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately $217.00. She thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Halima N.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 28 year-old Halima M.. She is married and has two children, aged seven and two. She has four dependents, who live with her because they are relatives. In 2006, Halima established her used clothing business. Halima requires a loan in order to buy more clothes in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Brigitha V.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 37 year-old Brigitha V. L..  She is married, and has three children aged 14,12 and 7. In 2000, Brigitha established her poultry farming business. 

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. 

First, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiple naturally. Second, they require little space, so you can let them run around in your garden or compound. Third, while they are growing, they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. 

Brigitha is requesting a loan in order to buy new chicks, drugs & food for the chickens. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy new chicks, drugs & food for the chickens.

loans.name: Huruma A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Huruma A. L..  She is married, and has one child, aged 1. She has two dependents, who live with her because they are orphans.  

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

In 2002, Huruma established her cereals business. The loan she is requesting is for that business so she can buy maize stock. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more maize stock

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en: S. Saodat was born in 1969 in Khujand. She is married and is a loving mother of two children. Mrs. S. Saodat trades women's wear in the local bazaar. She has engaged in commercial service and trade for 12 years, so she is experienced in business and has good skills. Mrs. S. Saodat has not had problems repaying previous loan. She has a good assortment of merchandise, works with straight suppliers, and trades at prices that are lower than other bazaar prices. Mrs. S. Saodat is applying to KIVA for a business development loan of 3100 STJ for 6 months so she can purchase new imported seasonal wear and widen her assortment.

loans.use: Import new seasonal women's wear and widen her assortment of merchandise

loans.name: Witnes S.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Witnes S. is 50 years old. She is married and has three children aged 26, 23, and 12. In 2006, Witnes started her used clothing business.

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed, and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers. The retailers then re-wash and re-iron the clothing and sell it on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially among the younger generation, because they are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything western or modern. Many people argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress; however, the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

Witnes is requesting a loan to buy more used clothing in bulk, so she can resell it. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing in bulk to resell

loans.name: Tutindaga L.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Tutindaga L. L. is 41 years old, is married, and has two children, ages 18 and 15. In 2004, Tutindaga started her clothing business.

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed, and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers. The retailers then re-wash and re-iron the clothing and sell it on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially among the younger generation, because the clothes are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything western or modern. Many people argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment, the growing market in used clothing is an important source of income for many micro-entrepreneurs.

Tutindaga has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requests a loan in order to buy more used clothing. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of clothing in bulk to resell in her community.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in clothing for a small business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of clothing to restock a small business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in a lot of products for a beauty salon.

loans.name: Nuriddin

texts.en:
Vegetable sales are a flourishing business in Tajikistan for the simple reason that every home needs vegetables. A. Nuriddin has been selling fruits and vegetables in Dushanbe for the past 2 years. He began his own stall with his hard-earned savings as he had always wanted to be an entrepreneur.

Nuriddin began selling in “Ganj” market with very little stock to offer his clients. Slowly he began to increase the goods offered until he managed to get a permanent market stall. Currently his stall is his pride and joy, with a zinc roof and ceramic tiles on the floor.

Nuriddin is the father of three young children who are in school. Like any father, he is doing his best in order to offer his children the best future and to make them well-educated. Now he needs a loan of 2400 Somoni ($700) in order to increase the stock of his goods. He promises to repay the loan within 3 months and expresses his gratitude to everyone for supporting him.

loans.use: Increase the range of vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a lot of materials to keep operating a small beauty salon.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of costume jewelry to add to a business of selling women's clothing.

loans.name: Vali

texts.en:
A. Vali is 42 years old. He is married with four children. Vali sells foodstuffs like tea, soft drinks, bread, chocolates and different kinds of sweets. He rents a place for selling which is located in one of the local markets. Vali has been running his own small business for 6 years. His wife is a housekeeper and she takes care of their children. His son, who is pictured on the photo with him, helps Vali with serving the clients.

The business is the main source of income at the same time requires considerable funding. Vali works very hard to give his dear children a good education and to make them happy. In order to cover the higher education expenses of his elder son as he’s going to enter the university, Vali is planning to increase his working capital and thus increase the range of his goods. With this purpose he requests 2800 Somoni ($825) for the term of 9 months.

Vali thanks everyone for their support and promises to pay the loan on time. Vali is counting on your help. You can be an important part of the growth of Vali’s business.

loans.use: Purchasing foodstuffs to increase his selection of goods.

loans.name: On

texts.en: Mrs. On P., 28, sells groceries from her house and she earns around $1.5 per day. Her husband, 51, Mr. Im Ourn, earns around $2 per day farming and selling pieces of wood. They have two children and live in Pongror Village, Kampong Cham Province. To expand their business, P. seeks a loan of $300 to purchase farmland for her husband's farming business. The loan will allow them to expand their farming business and improve the family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase farmland for her husband's farming business

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn S. raises pigs and lives in Romoul Village, Kampong Cham Province. She earns around $3 per day and her husband earns around $1.5 per day farming. They have five children, one of whom is married and three who work for a garment factory in Phnom Penh City. Because of her desire to expand her business and improve her family's income, she requests a loan of $700 to buy pig feed and purchase piglets to raise. They plan to use the remainder of the loan to repair their pigpen. The loan will allow them to expand the business and improve their family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise, buy pig feed, and repair their pigpen.

loans.name: Neng

texts.en: Mrs. Neng N. is a villager in Trapaing Ankrorng Village in Kampong Speu Province. She is a 48 year old mother of three children, one of whom is a white wine maker, while another is attending school. She owns a pig breeding business, but she does not have enough money to build a piggery during rainy season. She would like to ask for a loan to build it and use the rest of the money to buy more food to feed her pigs. Her husband, Mr. Chev Pheun, is a laborer in the local village. Previously, Mrs. Neng N. obtained a loan to buy pig food. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To build a piggery and buy more food to feed her pigs.

loans.name: Suk

texts.en: Mrs. Suk N., a subsistence farmer, lives in Ream Kandal Village in Kampong Speu Province. Mrs. Suk N. is 32 and the mother of five children, two of whom are attending school, while three are staying at home because they are too young to study or work. Her husband, Mr. Thim Tem, is a farmer. Mrs. Suk N. does not have enough money to buy cows to be draft animals to help her plow her rice field; therefore, she is requesting a loan to buy a new cow. Previously, Mrs. Suk N. obtained a loan from AMK to buy a section of rice field to cultivate rice. Her husband and her child are presented in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a new cow

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mrs. Ly P. and her husband, Mr. Nak Hin, are subsistence farmers in Trapaing Angkrorng Village in Kampong Speu Province.  She is 39 years old and married with three children, two of whom are attending school while the other is too young. During the rainy season, Mrs. Ly P. cultivates rice and during the dry season, she grows different kinds of vegetables. In her plantation business, Mrs. Ly P. always hires a laborer to plow her rice field because she does not own a draft animal. Mrs. Ly P. currently would like to plow the rice field by her self, therefore, she is asking for a loan to buy cows. Previously, Mrs. Ly P. obtained a loan to cultivate watermelons on her field. Her husband and her son are presented in the photo.

loans.use: To buy cows to plow her rice field.

loans.name: Ki

texts.en: Mrs. Ki T. is a villager in Kraing Ponhea Village in Kampong Speu Province. She is a subsistence farmer. Her husband, Mr. Sokhorn Tim, is a farmer and a construction worker. They have seven children: one is employed in a garment factory; another is working as a construction worker; four are attending school; and the youngest one is staying at home. Despite having four members of the family who earn money, they have been unable to raise sufficient funds to rebuild their house. In order to improve their living condition, Mrs. Ki T. would like to ask for a loan to build a new house. Previously, Mrs. Ki T. obtained a loan from AMK to buy a cart to transport fertilizers to fill in the field. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Malika

texts.ru:
Malika H. is a mother of two children. Her husband works in a company which manufactures wooden doors and windows. Malika has a specialized-secondary education and her specialization is a chief. She has been working as a chief in a prestigious restaurant called Piramida for the past ten years. She has a piece of land with an unfinished summer home and wants to get a loan to buy building materials, which has brought her to MicroInvest.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Хайдарова Малика , мать двоих детей ,муж работает в фирме по производству деревянных окон и дверей.Сама Малика имеет средне- специальное образвание по специальности повара, теперь она уже 10 лет как работает поваром в престижном ресторане, под названием Пирамида.Она имеет дачный участок где стоит недостроенный дом , она взяв кредит хочет закупить строй материалы.Для этого обратилась в Микроинвест

loans.use: Personal use

loans.name: Avashon

texts.en: A. Avashon has been a client of MicroInvest since 2004, so we have worked with this client for a long time. He has recommended himself as a serious client who has not had problems with loan repayments. The stability of his business stability has helped him to widen his existing business and open a trade outlet selling a variety of macaroni. He trades imported macaroni as well as product made in Tajikistan. He has a good assortment. Mr. A. Avashon has applied to KIVA for financial support through a business development loan of 1200 STJ for 4 months for to import new goods. Mr. A. Avashon thanks KIVA for its work and its help to the small business entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Import new goods for macaroni business

loans.name: Identity Protected

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 48 years old. He has 4 children. Two of them are studying at university. He has a small shop of spare parts for cars. He applied to borrow $1200 to purchase new spare parts, paint the shop, and make new shelves in order to increase his income and improve his life. He wants to save for a better life for his family.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase new spare parts

loans.name: Khursheda

texts.en: A. Khursheda has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2005. She is married and has 3 children. She lives in Khujand and is engaged in trade. She has traded furniture, towels, and underwear in the local bazaar for 12 years. Mrs. A. Khursheda has special business skills and she started the business many years ago from scratch. Now Mrs. A. Khursheda has applied to KIVA requesting a loan of 4100 STJ for 4 months to widen her assortment of merchandise and import new goods.

loans.use: Widen assortment and import new goods

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en: A. Mahbuba lives in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan. She is married and has 3 children. Mrs. A. Mahbuba has engaged in commercial service and trade for many years. She knows the market specifications and is experienced in business. Now Mrs. A. Mahbuba is engaged in a wholesale business, trading socks, headscarves, packages, and other items. Mrs. A. Mahbuba has applied to KIVA for help with a loan of 2100 STJ for 4 months to widen her assortment and import new goods.

loans.use: Widen assortment of merchandise and import new goods.

loans.name: Nury

texts.en: M. Nury lives in Khujand and is engaged in a small business selling small items and sundries. She trades thread, henna, packages, and other items. Mrs. M. Nury is an active client who we have been working with since 2003. The business and a stable income helped her to pay the previous loan on time and to improve her business significantly.  She started the business practically from the scratch. Now, M. Nury has applied to KIVA for help with a business development loan of 1500 STJ for 4 months for the new good importing.

loans.use: Import new goods.

loans.name: Berdikobul

texts.ru:
Berdikobul B. lives in the Vakhsh region. He lives with his family. He has 5 children and they all live together. Despite his age Berdikobul works and raises livestock. He raises young calves, fattens them and sells them to be slaughtered.

Right now there is a small crisis with feed due to weather conditions and as a result Berdikobul decided to take out a loan and to stock up on hay. This will help him to improve his situation a bit and will keep him from needing to sell his animals. Berdikobul plans to pay back the loan over a 9 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Бойназаров Бердикобул житель района Вахш. Живет со своей семьей. У него пятеро детей и живут они все вместе. Не смотря на свой возраст Бердикобул работает и занимается он животноводством. Имеет хозяйство , где выращивает молодых бычков . откармливает их и продает на мясо. Сейчас произошел небольшой кризис с кормами в связи с погодными условиями , поэтому он решил получить кредит и запастись сеном. Это поможет ему немного исправить ситуацию и не придется продавать животных. Погасить кредит он планирует в течении 9 месяцев

loans.use: Purchase Feed

loans.name: Gulijon

texts.ru:
Gulijon H. lives in the Vakhsh region. She is married and has one son. She is 29 years old and has been growing watermelons for 2 years. The melons have now ripened and they need to be harvested and driven to the market. This requires the rental of a truck and the purchase of gasoline. Gulijon plans to take out a loan for this purpose, which she will pay back over a 12 month period. This will help her to complete the harvest quicker and to earn a profit.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Хайруллоева Гулиджон жительница района Вахш. Замужем и имеет одного сына. В возрасте 29 лет она уже 2 года занимается выращиванием арбузов. Бахчевые поспели и их необходимо собирать и вывозить на базар. Но для этого нужно арендовать грузовую машину и закупить ГСМ. Поэтому она запланировала получить кредит , погасить который сможет в течении 6 месяцев. Это поможет быстрее реализовать урожай и получить прибыль.

loans.use: Purchase gasoline and rent a truck

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Further business development.

loans.name: Bahriddin

texts.ru:
Bahriddin T. lives in the Vakhsh region. He is 20 years old and has a high school education. Bahriddin lives with his pensioner parents. He has been raising livestock for more than 3 years. This business is the sole source of income for his family. Bahriddin purchases small calves at the market, fattens them for 45 days and sells them at the market at a favorable price. He plans to purchase two calves to fatten and needs a loan to do this. After discussing it with his family, Bahriddin decided to take out a loan for a 9 month period.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Тухтаев Бахриддин житель района Вахш. Возраст 20 лет, образование среднее. Бахриддин живет с родителями-пенсионерами. Он более 3 лет занимается животноводством. Эта деятельность является единственным источником дохода его семьи.Клиент покупает на рынке молодых бычков , откармливает их в течении 45 дней и продает на рынке по выгодной ему цене. В данный момент он планирует купить 2-х бычков для откормки.Для чего ему нужны деньги,посоветовавшись с семьей клиент решил взять кредит сроком на 9 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase two calves

loans.name: Mahramoy

texts.ru:
Mahramoy M. lives in Yavan. She is married and has 3 children. Mahramoy has been selling clothing, women’s fabrics and children’s clothing for 3 years. She sells her goods in villages by going door to door.

Mahramoy would like to increase her inventory and start selling items at a specific sales location. This will help her to acquire permanent customers and to increase profits. The loan will allow Mahramoy to stabilize her business. She will pay back the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Мирзоева Махрамо проживает в городе Яван . Замужем , имеет троих детей. Три года как занимается торговлей . продает одежду , женские ткани и детские вещи. Торгует в кишлаках из дома в дом. Хочет увеличить товарооборот и торговать с торговой точки.Это поможет приобрести постоянных клиентов и увеличить прибыльность дела. Благодоря кредиту она сможет стабилизировать свой бизнес. Погасить кредит она планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Increase Inventory

loans.name: Sophorn

texts.en: Mrs. Sophorn C., 43 years old, lives in Monorom Village in Kampong Speu Province. She is a mother of six children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory, while three others are currently in school. Mrs. Sophorn works in a plantation business while her husband, Mr. Loy Him makes beds, chairs and tables for sale. Mr. Loy Him’s business is improving, however he does not have enough money to buy more lumber to make his products.  Mrs. Sophorn C. would like to ask for a loan to buy more lumber her husband's business.  Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more lumber to make more beds, tables and chairs

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mr. Sopheap P., 30, and his wife, Mrs. Kunthea Mak, 33, who live along National Road Number Six, about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1996 and have two children, one daughter, who is in school, and one son.

Mr. Sopheap has been an electrician in a factory since 1996, while Mrs. Kunthea used to be a garment factory worker for many years as well but now she has stopped for a while to take care of their little son. Currently, the couple lives with their parents and are in the process of building their own house (shown in the picture) and lack some money to finish it. So, Sopheap is requesting a loan of US$800 to add to his own money to finish his house.

loans.use: Sopheap would like to finish building their new house.

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en: Mrs. Sokha Y. is a farmer in Tbeng Village in Kampong Speu Province. Aside from this business activity, Mrs. Sokha Y. is a pig breeder. Although Mrs. Sokha Y. has two business activities, her family conditions remain poor. To improve her family's condition, Mrs. Sokha Y. would like to start a cow breeding business and she is asking for a loan to buy a cow. Her husband, Mr. Meun Man, is a subsistence farmer. Mrs. Sokha Y. has four children, one of whom is working in a garment factory while another is attending school. The remaining two stay at home because they are too young. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To start a cow breeding business.

loans.name: Somaly

texts.en:
Mrs. Somaly S., 50, and her husband, Mr. Vuthy Im, 53, who live on an Island of Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1982 and have six children, three sons and three daughters. Three of her children have full time employment in Phnom Penh. Of her other three children, two are in local school and the youngest one stays at home.

Somaly has been a tailor for over twenty years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sews cloth to serve the villagers at her home, while Mr. Vuthy has been working at one NGO in Phnom Penh for twenty years. Somaly is requesting a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorcycle for her children to use for work.

loans.use: Somaly would like to purchase a motorcycle for her children to use for work.

loans.name: Moeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Moeurn S. lives in Tbeng Village in Kampong Speu Province. She is a subsistence farmer who usually cultivates twice a year. Aside of this business activity, Mrs. Moeurn S. is a firewood seller. Her husband, Mr. Ly Roeurn, is a house constructor as well as a palm juice collector in the village. Although, Mrs. Moeurn S.’s family members have different business activity, they remain in a poor living condition. In order to improve her living condition, Mrs. Moeurn S. would like to ask for a loan to start a cow breeding business. Mrs. Moeurn S. has three children, one of whom is attending school while the other two remain too young to study or work. Her husband is on the right of the picture.
